While it is true that people may occasionally provide false or inaccurate information on surveys, this does not necessarily make surveys a waste of time. 

Firstly, survey researchers are aware of this possible bias and employ statistical methods to try and minimize its effects. For instance, survey researchers can use specialized techniques to clean and validate the data, and measure response rates.

Secondly, researchers can measure the level of honesty of survey participants by embedding validation questions in the survey itself. These questions are designed to confirm the accuracy of the data provided by respondents, and help detect instances of false or inconsistent reporting. 

Thirdly, while some participants may be dishonest or inaccurate on surveys, this does not mean that all survey respondents are. For the majority of people, surveys provide a genuine opportunity for expressing their opinions and experiences to researchers, and help to make important decisions and conduct research across a wide array of fields.

Therefore, despite the fact that some people may provide untruthful information on surveys, surveys can still be valuable for generating useful information and insights for many purposes. Effective surveys are carefully crafted to minimize the chances of participants not providing accurate responses, but when invalid responses occur, following validations help to ascertain reliability.
